utterances: May I ask what kind of insurance you had?
We have USAA insurance, and we did not have flood insurance because we weren't required to.
We don't live in a flood zone, or didn't live in a flood zone.
Now we do.
You're going to rebuild a house on your property?
Fortunately, because we did not have any damage to our roof, we're able to rebuild our existing structure.
How long will rebuilding take?
Do you have any idea?
Ironically, we'll probably be finished about the time hurricane season is in full swing.
This year then?
Yes, we're hoping this year.
Do you mind if I ask--of all the things in your house, among your possessions that disappeared, what's been the hardest to bear?
Photos.
Definitely.
I love doing scrapbooking, so I had done our honeymoon and we had our wedding pictures and such, and, of course, my husband, yes, he did have a very large TV.
It was one of the last things that he put on the street.
We were actually eating lunch in the motor home at the time, and so we saw the people come and pick it up and he just kind of had to turn around and `I just don't want to see it.'
And who says men have no emotion.
Exactly.
Exactly.
So I've learned that I can live without quite a lot, but what's most important is being with the people and the animals that you love.
Thank you so much, Ms. Gillen.
You're welcome.
Lori Gillen of Gulf Breeze, Florida.

Let's start with Terry(ph), and Terry is on the line with us from Astoria in Oregon.
Hi.
Hi, Terry.
You're on the air.
What's the radio moment that changed your life?
My big moment, and I'll never forget it, was when Pearl Harbor was bombed and I was a child playing in the basement of New York.
And suddenly it came over the radio, Pearl Harbor has been bombed and my family started running around the house and - in panic.
I crawled underneath the table and put on my mother's spaghetti colander for my helmet and...
(LAUGHTER)
...and shot people as they went by the table.
And they were just, you know, getting more and more panicked.
And then FDR came on and said we are at war.
And it was...
That was the next day, yeah.
